column4: Ok I have ubuntu installed but in order to get my wifi going I need the kernel source.  Do I d/l the kernel deb file and install that?
Anyone?
you just install linux-source
deb package?
from synaptic or apt-get or deborphan or aptitude or [...]
no net connection that's why I'm asking if I need to d/l the deb, burn to cd and install that way?
that would work.
look on packages.ubuntu.com for the package
I tried that but they arent deb packages
the packages on packages.ubuntu.com surely are .deb packages
breezy, i386?
I tried those I few days ago and it didnt work, yeah intel
it didn't work how?
I can't remember exactly, I think it said something about how the package wasnt the right format
get this: http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/pool/main/l/linux-source-2.6.12/linux-source-2.6.12_2.6.12-9.23_all.deb
ah - except you probably just want the kernel HEADERS don't you?  not the full source?
Can't I just get the src from kernel.org and use that?
you need source which matches the kernel you're running.
no you dont
if you want to get the kernel.org source and build it and run that kernel, then that's fine, but it's probably a lot more work than you want to do
you can be running 2.4.x and install 2.6.x kernel source and it works fine
you can?
sure
why don't you do that then?
